title: Solr crashes on linux after doing lots of updates
description:
I am adding 500 results at a time then running the commit command, then sleeping for a second then adding 500 more etc.. But after about a million results i get this error:

comments.author: Yonik Seeley
comments.content:
> # An unexpected error has been detected by HotSpot Virtual Machine: 

Well, that one looks like a Sun JVM bug. 

> <result status="1">java.io.IOException: Lock obtain timed out: Lock@/tmp/lucene- 1dbe49e67a495d9cebacfbe2c40278c3-write.lock 

This one happened because the JVM died the first time and there was no opportunity to clean up the write lock for the index.
You either have to delete it manually, or tell Solr to delete it on startup.  See unlockOnStartup in solrconfig.xml

  <mainIndex>
    [...]
    <!-- If true, unlock any held write or commit locks on startup. 
         This defeats the locking mechanism that allows multiple
         processes to safely access a lucene index, and should be
         used with care. -->
    <unlockOnStartup>false</unlockOnStartup>
  </mainIndex>

> I am adding 500 results at a time then running the commit command, then sleeping for a second then adding 500 more etc.

Sleeping inbetween shouldn't be needed.
Here are some things to try to work around the JVM bug you hit:
  1) try running the JVM in -server mode instead (it's much faster anyway). 
  2) if the crash tends to happen after a certain number of documents are added, it could be the JVM running out of memory in a non-graceful way (crashing instead of throwing an OOM exception... I've seen it happen).  Try increasing the heap size of the JVM (-Xmx256m)

So try :  java -server -Xmx256m start.jar

if that still crashes, some other things to try: 
  3) see if there are any OS or libc patches for your OS
  4) make sure your hardware isn't flakey
  5) try running with tomcat as a servlet container
  6) try a different JVM (IBM, BEA, or downgrade to 1.5.0_05)

comments.author: Hoss Man
comments.content:
It might also be worth trying the -Xint option (which is suppose to disable JIT optimizations) ... the behavior pattern of "the system runs fine for a while, and then there is a HotSPot JVM crash" sounds a lot like there may be a bug in the HotSpot code optimization.

In any case, there's not much we can do about a JVM bug except try to narrow down the exact paramaters that trigger the bug (JVM/OS/etc...) and report it to the JVM Maintainer.

comments.author: Hoss Man
comments.content:
If you don't care what the id value is, you can allways remove the "uniqueKey" declaration from your schema – solr doesn't require you to have one.  You only need the "uniqueKey" declaration if you want Solr to automatically delete older versions of hte doc (based on id)  Based on your request, it seems like you don't care what the id's are, you just want to keep adding docs – eliminating uniqueKey will do that for you.


if you want to know the highest value in index for any (indexed, non-tokenized, sortable) field, you cna use a query like this...

http://localhost:8983/solr/select/?q=id:[*+TO+*];+id+desc&version=2.1&start=0&rows=1&fl=id&indent=on

...this is only safe if you're sure there are no pending updates (ie: you haven't added anything since the last commit)

comments.author: Hoss Man

(FYI: discussions like this probably make moresense on the user list where more people can see it and provide feedback .... i'm not sure if you are subscribed, so i'll reply here)

altering the schema won't affect the existing index in anyway.  i'm 99% sure that hte only thing the uniqueKey declaration is for is dup detection when adding docs, so if you remove it, your index should still be 100% viable.
